intro: Caraguata bakeri, commonly known as the Baker's caraguata, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its woody stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in rocky or mountainous terrain. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it remains relatively rare in horticultural trade.
